ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: investment analysis and endowment practice
A wholesale introduction to the diverse world of investment management, at the bird's eye view of original source of capital.
Learned about how the Yale endowment works
I gained an overview of the investment management/endowment industry. The speakers were really interesting!
I gained a high-level overview of how the the Yale Investments Office serves the university.
I learned the fundamentals of institutional investing through world class investors and teachers.
I learned about endowment and foundation investing, as well as investing concepts more broadly.
Class
Institutional Investing

Absolutely incredible class. So much insight into asset allocation, into how excellent investors in every asset class work, into how to be both ethical and committed to superior performance. Wonderful instructors, wonderful financial writing assignments (excellent critical thinking opportunities through the 4 writing assignments in particular) and an awesome TA, Joe Doran, as well. Thanks to Amy and Alex for everything.
i learned about what to think of when designing a portfolio and considering different managers.
An in-depth understanding of how institutional investors like the Yale Endowment operates and selects external managers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: perfect
Terrific course. Perfectly balances theory and practice, and is so doing enriches both. A true firehose of knowledge.

strengths: interesting to learn material from people who work at the Yale Endowment 
fun to talk to experienced managers 

weaknesses: what we learned in class wasn't very relevant to what we were being graded on for assignments (evaluating managers). Getting a good grade on these assignments was more about copying everything managers said during class rather than learning how to critique them. Overall not a very enjoyable course but has potential.

This is a very high-engagement course with fascinating speakers. All the students were very driven and curious about what exactly the endowment does. It was also very clear how much thought the Investments Office puts into the course, as everything has a clear purpose. The only thing I think could be improved was just the communication at times, as there were a couple of times when a major assignment was given less than a week before it was due.

You need to be able to take good notes during the speaker presentations in order to do well because your grade is based primarily on essays from their presentations. I think this class really helps build that skill and the speakers are extremely engaging.

Strengths included the course being taught by investors in the Yale Investments Office and the opportunity to interact with and learn from outside managers. I cannot think of much that could be improved.
Everything was great

I loved the seminar setting with the speakers every other week. This course could be improved with more engagement from the professors, like using office hours. I think it could also be interesting if the course was more connected with the investments office. I think that the presentations could have been announced with more warning.

The teaching staff and the guest speakers are truly enlightening in ways beyond description. The opportunity to have in-depth conversations with some of the most legendary investors is priceless. 
Weakness? I wish the class sessions could be longer!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes
A must-take for those interested in investing, and to be honest, a important crash course for those who aren't as well.
I would! It was a great way to learn first hand from industry leaders! You get out of the class what you put into it.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. If you get in, you must take this course. Not only is it an incredible way to learn about how the Investments Office manages the endowment, but you get to hear from numerous impressive guest lecturers from the world's leading investment managers. This course is an opportunity to learn from so many great minds that you cannot get anywhere else.
Absolutely! This is a staple class you should definitely take if you can get in. The workload is manageable and is very applicable to the real world of investing
Yes, great class! Learn about everything from the allocator perspective from the best team to ever do it, take if you have the chance.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone focused on a career in investing.
Yes
Highly. If you have a spot, you simply have to take it - there's a reason you applied, and trust me, you were right.
yes! great class to take if you get accepted. the professors are very sweet and you meet many cool people!
Yes. Please take it if you can. People would say it is what you make of it, but I do think this is one of the best classes I have taken at Yale.
